title: Stefon Diggs hopes Super Bowl LX can strengthen Hall of Fame case. Would a win put Patriots’ WR in Canton?
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Stefon Diggs aims to strengthen his Hall of Fame case with a Super Bowl LX victory.
Diggs has four Pro Bowl selections, one first-team All-Pro, and two All-Pro nods in his career.
Diggs ranks 38th in receiving yards and 43rd in touchdowns, with potential to climb higher.

title: Would the Patriots’ dynasty have ever happened without new Hall of Famer Adam Vinatieri?
author: Chad Finn
bullets: Adam Vinatieri, former Patriots and Colts kicker, was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame on Thursday.
Vinatieri played 24 NFL seasons, scoring the most points in history with 2,673, and winning four Super Bowls.
His notable kicks include game-winners in Super Bowl XXXVI and XXXVIII, defining the Patriots' initial championship success.

title: Mike Vrabel throws a wrinkle in Patriots’ final practice ahead of Super Bowl LX
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Mike Vrabel simulated a long Super Bowl halftime during Patriots' practice by sending players to the locker room mid-session.
Patriots' quarterback Drake Maye participated fully in practice despite a recent shoulder issue, staying late with teammates.
Edge rusher Harold Landry III and linebacker Robert Spillane were limited in practice with injuries, while Joshua Farmer remains questionable.

title: Patriots-Seahawks Super Bowl will likely come down to which quarterback makes the fewest mistakes
author: Chad Finn
bullets: The Super Bowl LX matchup features quarterbacks Drake Maye and Sam Darnold, both former No. 3 overall picks.
The Patriots' defense, led by Milton Williams, has allowed just 8.7 points per game in the postseason.
Seahawks receiver Jaxon Smith-Njigba leads the league with 1,793 receiving yards, posing a key challenge for the Patriots.

title: Mass. company pleads guilty to OSHA violation that led to employee’s death
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: John Oliveira & Sons Stamp Concrete, Inc. pleaded guilty to OSHA violations after an employee's death at an East Freetown site.
The worker, Josué Tiquiram, was crushed by a malfunctioning tail conveyor lacking a safety device, leading to his death.
The company could face up to five years of probation, a $500,000 fine, and restitution; sentencing is on May 4.

title: Here’s what Healey put up in her Super Bowl bet with Washington state governor
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Massachusetts Gov. Maura Healey wagered Legal Sea Foods' chowder and Dunkin' coffee against Washington's Gov. Bob Ferguson for Super Bowl LX.
Healey's bet supports Massachusetts' identity, while Ferguson offers Washington's shellfish and coffee if the Patriots win.
Gov. Healey will attend Super Bowl LX in California as part of a trip supporting Democratic governors, with non-taxpayer funding.

title: Woman convicted of fraud after living under a stolen identity for more than 20 years
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Lina Maria Orovio-Hernandez convicted of multiple identity theft charges in Boston, living under a stolen identity for 20 years.
Orovio-Hernandez collected $400,000 in stolen federal benefits, including Section 8, Social Security, and SNAP assistance.
Convictions include fraudulent voting and false statements; she faces potential prison time, fines, and deportation.

title: Celtics rally from 22 down in Vucevic’s debut to beat Heat: 6 takeaways
author: Tom Westerholm
bullets: Nikola Vucevic debuted for the Celtics with 11 points and 12 rebounds, helping them to a 98-96 comeback win over the Heat.
Payton Pritchard sparked a third-quarter rally, scoring 16 points in an 11-minute span, helping erase a 21-point deficit.
Derrick White's late 3-pointer secured the Celtics' comeback win, moving them to second place after the Knicks' loss to the Pistons.

title: Tom Brady shows support for Patriots ahead of Super Bowl LX after saying he ‘doesn’t have a dog in the fight’
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Tom Brady initially stated he wasn't rooting for the Patriots in Super Bowl LX, citing his role as a Raiders owner.
Brady later expressed support for Patriots owner Robert Kraft on Instagram, urging the team to win a seventh Super Bowl.
Brady's comments drew criticism from former teammates Vince Wilfork and Robert Spillane for his lack of clear support.

title: Former Colts Pro Bowl center thinks Drake Maye should have won NFL MVP over Matthew Stafford
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Jeff Saturday believes Patriots QB Drake Maye deserved the NFL MVP over Rams QB Matthew Stafford.
Saturday cites Maye's higher QBR and performance against common opponents to support his opinion.
ESPN analyst Mina Kimes also voted for Maye, highlighting his rushing ability and statistical dominance.
